title: Part A
stimulusHtml:
1 point is earned for the correct formula.

ClF
descriptions:

title: Part B
stimulusHtml:
1 point is earned for a central Cl atom surrounded by three bounding pairs with F atoms and two nonbonding (lone) pairs of electrons. F atoms must have three nonbonding pairs each. Electron pairs can be depicted as dots or line segments.

See diagram above.

See diagram above.

The student response earns one of the following points:

1 point is earned for a central Cl atom surrounded by three bounding pairs with F atoms and two nonbonding (lone) pairs of electrons. F atoms must have three nonbonding pairs each. Electron pairs can be depicted as dots or line segments.

title: Part C
stimulusHtml:
1 point is earned for indicating that the molecule is T-shaped with an acceptable explanation.

The molecule is T-shaped

because a T-shaped structure is asymmetric with dipoles that do not cancel out, but produce a net dipole (i.e., a polar molecule).

OR

because, if the molecule had a trigonal planar structure, the molecule would be symmetric with dipoles that cancel out and produce a net dipole of zero (i.e., a nonpolar molecule), which is not consistent with the observation that the ClF3 molecule does have a dipole moment.
descriptions:

The student response earns one of the following points:

1 point is earned for indicating that the molecule is T-shaped with an acceptable explanation.

The molecule is T-shaped

because a T-shaped structure is asymmetric with dipoles that do not cancel out, but produce a net dipole (i.e., a polar molecule).

OR

title: Part D
stimulusHtml:
1 point is earned for an acceptably modified hypothesis that addresses both atomic structure and periodicity.

An acceptable hypothesis (descriptive or formulaic) must include the following ideas:

  • Atomic Structure: e.g., odd number of F atoms

  • Periodicity: e.g., as the atomic number of the central halogen atom increases, the number of F atoms increases
